text: Small watchtowers built in lonely, desolate regions where few others care to visit - the heartlands of marshes, swamps and moors or ragged cliffs with treacherous reefs beyond.
Usually shrouded in mist or obscured by rain and dark clouds; travellers are often on the outskirts of a Fimir stronghold before they are aware of it.
Settlements are highly variable in layout and always take advantage of natural defensive features in the landscape. Sometimes they even build such features with the raw muscle of the Shearl.
Fimir strongholds take the form of forbidding, craggy piles of rock, crudely built in the semblance of the fortifications of more civilised races.
Some remote, ancient and well-hidden Fimir strongholds have grown and expanded over the centuries into truly forbidding edifices.
Crude buildings where the members of the slave caste live until they are no longer useful.
Each caste has its own communal buildings, but those of the Shearls do not offer much comfort.
Warriors of the Fimm caste train and live together. They are always ready to protect the clan.
Daemonic creatures roam the marshes around the Fimir settlements, preying on the unwary.
Since the Fimir are few in number, they rely heavily on their swamp-dwelling servants.
Mounted troops pose a threat to the Fimm Warriors. However, they are at a severe disadvantage against vicious demons that charge unhindered through the swamps...
The Fimir almost never fight mounted, but when they do, the mount must be as merciless and deadly as they are.
Various titles are awarded to Fimm who experience significant events or who successfully face and overcome certain challenges in battle, and are taken as indication of an individual's prowess.
The largest and strongest of their kind, the warrior elite of the Fimm caste, live in separate quarters.
The Fianna have access to the best weapons and armour, such as the heavy two-handed maces studded with glyphs.
Every clan has a small cabal of Balefiend Apprentices that are eagerly learning the dark arts from the more experienced Dirachs.
Here the Dirachs are practicing the art of creating the magical constructs, Fenbeasts, to serve their every whim.
The eldest Dirachs have mastered the art of binding the mightiest of the swamp dwellers to their will.
Daemons are an integral part of the Fimir war parties and are summoned in great numbers.
By binding a Daemon into the body of a Fimm Warrior, the Dirachs create terrifying living weapons. After the ritual, however, there is nothing left of the warrior's mind.
While not entirely welcoming to other nomadic Fimir, they are open to the trading of trinkets and slaves.
The presence of prisoners is a normal part of Fimir existence. The unfortunate souls caught in raids are locked up in crude pens.

Prisoners are guarded by enough Shearl or Fimm to prevent escape. The conditions of captivity are tolerable, as the Shearl regularly clean up and feed their prisoners - females in particular are well looked after, though heavily guarded.
The largest settlements have deep dungeons housing countless prisoners, who are vital to the preservation of the Fimir.
Shearl craftsmen make use of natural materials whenever possible, especially long grasses for making rough clothing, rope and nets, stone, bone and wood for weapons and building materials.
The Dirachs like to decorate their robes with small trinkets that are also used for trading.
Some Shearl show talent for certain skills, such as wood or metalworking, boat-building or net-making, and so on.
Some Fimir, usually Dirach or Shearl, are able to play a crude bagpipe-like instrument. Musical story-telling sessions are whole-clan events and serve to strengthen clan bonds.

During their free time, Fimir indulge in tattooing, and to a lesser extent scarification; a few clans practice branding. Most often, these activities are social acts, with Fimir of the same caste tattooing one another.
Wrestling competitions are held by the Shearl and the Fimm (within, rarely between, castes), which the whole clan, including the Meargh, comes to watch.
Wharfs are platforms jutting out of the water, allowing ships to be boarded easily.
The Fimir build longships similar to those of the Northmen, but made of a hard, black wood.
From their ports, the fog-shrouded longships of the Fimir set out to raid ships and coastal villages alike.
This once-bustling port lies in ruins. Nothing remains but destruction, ashes and the sorrowful taste of defeat.
Many clans grow carnivorous plants such as Bloodsedge outside the stronghold boundaries.
In addition to embankments, ditches and moats, the Fimir also defend their strongholds with palisades of sharpened posts.
Fimir build dry-stone walls as many other races do, an inner wooden wall supporting an outer dry-stone wall directly against it is not uncommon.
The Fimir post sentries and patrol their territory to intercept intruders before they can even find the stronghold.
Fimm Warriors on garrison duty are tasked with protecting the settlement and the clan.
Due to their reclusive nature, it is very rare for Fimir to be present in a foreign settlement.
This district is shrouded in dense fog to protect its inhabitants from the hated sunlight.
A Fimir colony within an allied settlement does not raid surrounding villages to avoid destruction. Occasionally, however, some of the locals disappear.
Usually it is the Fimir who raid others, but they still need to remain vigilant themselves.

Dedicated to the foul Daemon Princess Kroll, All-Mother of the Marshes and Bogs, the sacrifices and worship offered at this temples empower her physical manifestation in this world.
After centuries of hiding, the Fimir have finally reclaimed their ancient homeland and birthplace.
The largest swamp in the Empire has been a refuge of the Fimir for ages.
The Marshes of Maddness stretch over huge swathes of the Badlands. Here the Fimir set their traps, capturing slaves and looting those fortunate enough to die.
Like any Meargh, Skattach has a grimlooking tower to rule from, echoing Fimir legends of a capital with a vast obsidian castle at the heart of the mysterious Wandering Island.
From this land, Kroll will turn the whole world into a huge bog and rise to godhood.
A small gathering place by bogs, rivers or the sea to carry out the Fimir's gruesome sacrifices.
Debris is removed and the brush cut back, to allow for larger sacrificial spectacles.
There are no sacrificial slabs or altars but larger settlements construct platforms for convenience.
